issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: This issue has been validated/reproduced, but has not been prioritized yet.
status.name: Confirmed

fields.description:
*Assessment*

Eucalyptus CloudWatch should list metrics if monitoring is disabled.  In AWS, CloudWatch metrics can be listed, even when monitoring is disabled.

*Signs*

Users are able to list cloudwatch metrics on AWS, but not able to on Eucalyptus, even though monitoring is disabled. Although this testing is ran from inside the instance using instance profiles, this can be seen from using the commandline tools as well.

_AWS_
{code}
$ ec2-describe-instances
RESERVATION	r-e0469d83	986451091583	default
INSTANCE	i-ad0353d7	ami-65a2f40c	ec2-54-205-97-173.compute-1.amazonaws.com	ip-10-170-36-104.ec2.internal	running	hspencer-test	0		m1.small	2013-10-14T00:18:23+0000	us-east-1a	aki-88aa75e1			monitoring-disabled	54.205.97.173	10.170.36.104			instance-store					paravirtual	xen		sg-c09762a8	default	false	arn:aws:iam::986451091583:instance-profile/instances-cloudwatch-actions

### From inside instance using boto ###
ubuntu@ip-10-170-36-104:~$ ipython
Python 2.7.4 (default, Sep 26 2013, 03:20:26)
Type "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

IPython 0.13.2 -- An enhanced Interactive Python.
?         -> Introduction and overview of IPython's features.
%quickref -> Quick reference.
help      -> Python's own help system.
object?   -> Details about 'object', use 'object??' for extra details.

In [1]: import boto

In [2]: cloudwatch = boto.connect_cloudwatch()

In [3]: cloudwatch.list_metrics()
Out[3]:
[Metric:NetworkOut,

_Eucalyptus_
{code}
# euca-describe-instances --region account1-user02@
RESERVATION	r-EF7E4079	735723906303	default
INSTANCE	i-6AE74024	emi-C25538DA	10.104.7.21	172.17.186.10	running	account1-user02	0		m1.large	2013-10-13T14:06:18.657Z	Legend	eki-C9083808	eri-39BC3B99		monitoring-disabled	10.104.7.21	172.17.186.10			instance-store					paravirtualized

### From inside instance using boto ###
ubuntu@ip-172-17-186-10:~$ ipython
Python 2.7.4 (default, Sep 26 2013, 03:20:26)
Type "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

IPython 0.13.2 -- An enhanced Interactive Python.
?         -> Introduction and overview of IPython's features.
%quickref -> Quick reference.
help      -> Python's own help system.
object?   -> Details about 'object', use 'object??' for extra details.

In [1]: import boto

In [2]: boto.set_stream_logger('paws')

In [3]: cloudwatch = boto.connect_cloudwatch(is_secure=False,debug=2,port='8773',path='/services/CloudWatch/')
2013-10-13 16:15:20,148 paws [DEBUG]:Retrieving credentials from metadata server.

10.104.10.6:8773
/services/CloudWatch/
AWSAccessKeyId=AKILSMTS9OO2IGWEEPCS&Action=ListMetrics&SecurityToken=ZXVjYQABRLXZijnVSn9bBxHRVXklzYbnnMGKFOBy3N7zqoOhnepcc98%2BRV7KVTJkfOAkItouZJ0V0u%2FaGYjZpPUyB4JW39kvchNqhSebESGDQFZgZe18QVZUiwCgVZvDQmUudAadReDj%2BsD0k%2B3w65SdZWUvQAEocw%2BimSYOk28mlhgk8eAuD4OLzTwsFkYH8JUJH5NtLv6YMbnA%2FMbkJ5rsOuk5%2F0LBiIHT8FGxG1Oy9fiogbIx5dvrLuqI&SignatureMethod=HmacSHA256&SignatureVersion=2&Timestamp=2013-10-13T23%3A15%3A24Z&Version=2010-08-01

2013-10-13 16:15:24,429 paws [DEBUG]:query_string: AWSAccessKeyId=AKILSMTS9OO2IGWEEPCS&Action=ListMetrics&SecurityToken=ZXVjYQABRLXZijnVSn9bBxHRVXklzYbnnMGKFOBy3N7zqoOhnepcc98%2BRV7KVTJkfOAkItouZJ0V0u%2FaGYjZpPUyB4JW39kvchNqhSebESGDQFZgZe18QVZUiwCgVZvDQmUudAadReDj%2BsD0k%2B3w65SdZWUvQAEocw%2BimSYOk28mlhgk8eAuD4OLzTwsFkYH8JUJH5NtLv6YMbnA%2FMbkJ5rsOuk5%2F0LBiIHT8FGxG1Oy9fiogbIx5dvrLuqI&SignatureMethod=HmacSHA256&SignatureVersion=2&Timestamp=2013-10-13T23%3A15%3A24Z&Version=2010-08-01 Signature: NuXLH3ilw2SP8RqQo41rmUq6ZIu+iUfK90lbw4woauE=
2013-10-13 16:15:26,166 paws [DEBUG]:<ListMetricsResponse xmlns="http://monitoring.amazonaws.com/doc/2010-08-01/"><ListMetricsResult><Metrics/></ListMetricsResult><ResponseMetadata><RequestId>2c7db068-4369-41eb-9354-42ba864360da</RequestId></ResponseMetadata></ListMetricsResponse>
Out[4]: []
{code}

*Steps*

* Setup Eucalyptus 3.4
* Add an IAM policy that enables EC2 (to run instances) and all CloudWatch actions
* Launch an instance with monitoring disabled
* Run euwatch-list-metrics

*Pertinent Data*

If there is a desire to test with boto, make sure and setup the [boto configuration file|http://boto.readthedocs.org/en/latest/boto_config_tut.html].  The boto configuration file needed to work with Eucalyptus needs to be similar to the following:
{code}
ubuntu@ip-172-17-186-10:~$ cat .boto
[Boto]
cloudwatch_region_endpoint = 10.104.10.6:8773
{code}

*Workaround*

Workaround is to enable cloudwatch monitoring on instances, and then metrics will be displayed.
fields.summary: List Metrics Doesn't Return Metrics If Monitoring is Disabled
fields.environment:
*non-HA*

* multi-cluster, Managed mode
* one cluster has SC SAN (Equallogic); other cluster has SC Overlay (tgtd)
{code}
SERVICE	jetty          	eucalyptus     	10.104.10.6    	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.10.6:8773/services/Jetty  	arn:euca:eucalyptus::jetty:10.104.10.6/
SERVICE	loadbalancing  	loadbalancing  	10.104.10.6    	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.10.6:8773/services/LoadBalancing	arn:euca:eucalyptus:loadbalancing:loadbalancing:10.104.10.6/

SERVICE	storage        	Exodus         	TheHeathen     	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.10.22:8773/services/Storage	arn:euca:eucalyptus:Exodus:storage:TheHeathen/
SERVICE	storage        	Legend         	NoWomanNoCry   	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.1.185:8773/services/Storage	arn:euca:eucalyptus:Legend:storage:NoWomanNoCry/
SERVICE	tokens         	eucalyptus     	10.104.10.6    	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.10.6:8773/services/Tokens 	arn:euca:eucalyptus::tokens:10.104.10.6/
SERVICE	eucalyptus     	eucalyptus     	10.104.10.6    	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.10.6:8773/services/Eucalyptus	arn:euca:eucalyptus:::10.104.10.6/
SERVICE	euare          	eucalyptus     	10.104.10.6    	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.10.6:8773/services/Euare  	arn:euca:eucalyptus::euare:10.104.10.6/

SERVICE	cluster        	Exodus         	NaturalMystic  	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.10.22:8774/axis2/services/EucalyptusCC	arn:euca:eucalyptus:Exodus:cluster:NaturalMystic/
SERVICE	cluster        	Legend         	IsThisLove     	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.1.185:8774/axis2/services/EucalyptusCC	arn:euca:eucalyptus:Legend:cluster:IsThisLove/
SERVICE	dns            	eucalyptus     	10.104.10.6    	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.10.6:8773/services/Dns    	arn:euca:eucalyptus::dns:10.104.10.6/
SERVICE	reporting      	bootstrap      	10.104.10.6    	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.10.6:8773/services/Reporting	arn:euca:bootstrap::reporting:10.104.10.6/
SERVICE	walrus         	walrus         	StirItUp       	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.10.6:8773/services/Walrus 	arn:euca:bootstrap:walrus:walrus:StirItUp/

SERVICE	cloudwatch     	cloudwatch     	10.104.10.6    	ENABLED   	30  	http://10.104.10.6:8773/services/CloudWatch	arn:euca:eucalyptus:cloudwatch:cloudwatch:10.104.10.6/
{code}

comments.body: [~ethomas], please update the design docs to clarify the enabled flag for instances.
[~ethomas] Any pointers on how and if,  we can address this? How can we return just the metric names when monitoring is not enabled on an instance?
[~mmunn1], I think this is more of a feature request. If we performed monitoring for instances without detailed monitoring enabled (as AWS/EC2 does) then we would have metrics to list.

[~mmunn1]  The issue here is our definition of 'monitoring' is different than AWS.  For us 'monitoring' off puts no data at all into CW for EC2.  It is then correct that we should have no metrics for these instances.  Monitoring 'on' puts data into EC2 with timing based on config parameters.  AWS ALWAYS puts data into CW for EC2, 'monitoring' on or off.  Monitoring off just puts data in every 5 minutes, monitoring on puts data in every minute.  The system is 'correct' as is right now based on our definitions.  In order to fix this, we would need to fix the describe sensor callback call to interpret monitoring more in line with what AWS does.  I would hold off on this for now, as we are in the middle of CW-ility work which may make changes in that area.
